title: What causes the phases of the moon?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary source of light in the solar system?

options.label: A
options.text: The Earth blocks the light from the Sun

options.label: B
options.text: The Sun and the Moon's relative positions

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's shadow on the Moon

options.label: D
options.text: The Sun and the Moon's relative positions

options.label: A
options.text: The Moon is moving away from the Earth

options.label: B
options.text: The Moon's orbit is tilted slightly to the Earth's orbit

options.label: C
options.text: The Earth's atmosphere is too thin

options.label: D
options.text: The Moon is in the Earth's shadow

options.label: A
options.text: When the Moon is in the Earth's shadow

options.label: B
options.text: When the Earth is in the Moon's shadow

options.label: C
options.text: When the Sun is in the Moon's shadow

options.label: D
options.text: When the Moon is in the Sun's shadow

multiple-choice.question: Why does the Moon turn red during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the Earth's shadow on the Moon

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the Moon's orbit around the Earth

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the Sun's position in the sky

options.label: A
options.text: To predict the weather on Earth

options.label: C
options.text: To infer the atmosphere of an exoplanet

options.label: A

options.label: A

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to predict the weather on Earth

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Myths you learned in health class

multiple-choice.question: What was the main goal of teaching students about health in American schools, as advocated by Benjamin Franklin?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To educate students about the importance of mental health

options.label: C
options.text: To teach students how to eat right and stay fit

options.text: To promote healthy habits and wellness

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the food pyramid introduced in 1992, and what was its main message?

options.label: A
options.text: The 1992 Food Pyramid, which emphasized the importance of limiting fats and sweets

options.label: B
options.text: The Healthy Plate, which promoted a balanced diet with fruits, veggies, and whole grains

options.label: C
options.text: The 1992 Food Pyramid, which encouraged up to 11 servings of bread, cereal, rice, and pasta daily

options.label: D
options.text: The Food Pyramid, which separated healthy whole grains from refined grains

title: How well do masks work?

options.text: To compare the effectiveness of different learning styles

options.text: A single test to determine the learning style of students

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why does smoke follow you around a fire?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why smoke from a fire keeps blowing back into your face?

options.label: A
options.text: The fire is too small to produce enough smoke.

options.label: B
options.text: The air near the fire becomes less dense than the air around it, causing it to rise and then be pushed back down by the surrounding air.

options.label: C
options.text: The smoke is being blown by an outside wind.

options.label: D
options.text: You block the airflow behind you with your body, creating a vacuum that pulls the air and smoke towards you.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the air near a fire as it heats up?

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes less dense and starts to rise.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the movement of air due to differences in density?
Why does less-dense air rise?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it weighs less than the air it replaces.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is colder than the surrounding air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is under the influence of gravity.

options.label: A
options.text: Because the force of gravity on their bodies pulls them down more than the air pushes them up.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the air is too dense to support their weight.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the objects are too heavy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the objects are too light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon where hot air rises and is replaced by cooler air, which is then heated and rises?
What is the main idea behind smokeless fire pits?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a vacuum that pulls smoke away from the fire.

options.label: B
options.text: To create additional paths for incoming air, reducing or eliminating smoke production.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the size of the fire.

options.label: D
options.text: To make the fire more visible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of having everyone spaced out equally when there is no outside wind?

options.label: A
options.text: The same amount of air is blocked from all directions, and nobody's vacuum is stronger than anyone else's.

options.label: B
options.text: The air is pushed away from the fire.

multiple-choice.question: Why do water waves have different speeds?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the shape of the boat.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the speed of the boat.

options.label: C
options.text: Because longer waves travel faster, while shorter waves travel slower, due to the phenomenon of dispersion.

options.label: C

options.text: Because faster waves have shorter wavelengths.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: It creates a series of circular waves.

options.label: D

options.text: Extremely active and producing excess energy

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the wood frog's heart during the winter months?

options.label: A
options.text: It beats rapidly to maintain body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: It stops beating to conserve energy

options.label: C
options.text: It beats slowly to conserve energy

options.label: D
options.text: It remains unchanged and continues to beat normally

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how long does it take for the wood frog's cells to rehydrate and return to their original shape after thawing?
How long can the wood frog survive with its body completely frozen?

options.label: A
options.text: A few days to several weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Forever in a state of suspended animation

multiple-choice.question: What is the first thing the wood frog does after coming back to life in the spring?

options.label: A
options.text: It finds a new home and settles in

options.label: B
options.text: It looks for food and starts to eat

options.label: C
options.text: It finds a mate and starts to breed

options.label: D
options.text: It rests for a while to recover from its frozen state

multiple-choice.question: What is the wood frog's state after coming back to life in the spring?

options.label: A
options.text: It is weak and tired from its frozen state

options.label: B
options.text: It is healthy and active, ready to start its new life

options.label: C
options.text: It is frozen and unable to move

options.label: D
options.text: It is hungry and looking for food
